resources.string: Enter the server\'s IP address or hostname (e.g., 192.168.1.1).
Enter the port number used for communication. Default is 5201.

Choose the protocol to use for the test:

 • TCP — Reliable protocol for throughput measurement with acknowledgments and congestion control. Ideal for stable links.

 • UDP — Lightweight protocol for speed testing without acknowledgments. Simulates real-time traffic like video or voice. Requires manual bandwidth setting.

 • UDP Incremental Ramp-Up Test — 📈 Gradually increases UDP bandwidth by 50 Mbps per iteration until the defined target is reached. Helps evaluate how performance scales under increasing load.

 • TCP + UDP Hybrid Strategy — 🔄 Runs an initial TCP test to estimate maximum bandwidth, then uses that result to configure UDP bandwidth automatically. Combines accuracy with high-speed testing.

 • Smart Ramp-Up Strategy — 🤖 Dynamically adjusts UDP bandwidth based on actual performance in previous iterations. Increases bandwidth only if at least 90% of the current step was achieved, ensuring adaptive scaling.

 ✅ Recommended: Use Hybrid or Smart Ramp-Up for optimized and automated test planning.
Duration in seconds for how long the test should run.\n\nExample: 60
Set the bandwidth (in Mbps) for UDP tests.\n\nExample: 100
Number of parallel streams used during the test.\n\nExample: 1
Time interval in seconds for each report during the test.\n\nExample: 1

Choose the direction of the test:

 • Upload — 📤 Sends data from your device to the server. Useful for testing outbound bandwidth and upstream performance.

 • Download (-R) — 📥 Server sends data to your device. Tests inbound bandwidth and download performance. Uses the `-R` (reverse) flag.

 • Bidirectional (--bidir) — 🔁 Performs both upload and download tests simultaneously. Gives a complete view of network performance. Uses the `--bidir` option.

 💡 Tip: Use Bidirectional to quickly assess both upload and download throughput in one go.
Number of times to repeat the test.\n\nExample: 3
Wait time in seconds between repeated test iterations.\n\nExample: 15

• 🐛 Debug — Enables technical logs for troubleshooting.

 • 📋 Verbose — Enables detailed per-second output from iPerf.

 • 📉 Auto Reduce Bandwidth on Packet Loss —

During UDP tests, this option monitors for high packet loss.

If a threshold is reached, a dialog will appear suggesting to reduce bandwidth.

By default, it will auto-accept after 5 seconds to help improve stability.
